item.title: Black Ops 6 Zombies Grief Mode, Explained
item.description:
Zombies mode in Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 has returned with a ton of content for players to enjoy, including Easter eggs and countless secrets to uncover that continue the mode’s storyline. Among the highlights, the Treyarch team has brought back Grief mode.

This mode changes the core rules of the traditional Zombies experience that most Call of Duty players are familiar with, turning it into a team-based competition with various modifiers that can either help or hinder progress toward the objective and winning the match. With that said, here’s a complete breakdown of how Grief mode works in Black Ops 6 .

What is Grief Zombies Mode in Call of Duty: Black Ops 6?

The Grief mode in Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 Zombies is a 4v4 indirect PvP mode where two teams of real players compete in the same match to survive as many zombie waves as possible — waves that are more populated than in the Standard mode. Teams cannot damage each other directly with weapons or equipment, but they must outplay the opposing team using Capture Zones and Griefs to weaken them and gain the upper hand.

While shooting enemies doesn’t deal damage, it can slow them down, making it easier for zombies to take them out. Melee attacks also push and slow enemy players, but this effect only applies during the actual attack. Additionally, players can’t pass through one another, allowing you to use your body as a blocker to disrupt opponents.

The Grief Zombies mode can be played on any of the available Black Ops 6 Zombies maps, including Liberty Falls, Terminus, Citadelle des Morts, The Tomb, and Shattered Veil.

To win a game of Grief, your team must be the last one standing , meaning all opposing players must be dead or downed at the same time. The mode includes respawn rounds every three rounds, allowing eliminated enemies to return — though with reduced gear.

Black Ops 6 Grief Zombies Capture Zones, Explained

Capture Zones appear frequently during matches in Black Ops 6 ’s Grief mode. Once activated, both teams compete to eliminate zombies within the zone before their opponents . The HUD displays how many enemies each team and player must kill. Objectives may vary — from general kills to specific types like Critical Kills, Support and Equipment Kills, or Melee Kills. Players can choose to either focus on completing their objective quickly or disrupt the opposing team’s progress.

When a Capture Zone is secured, the team that failed to capture it will be sent into a Grief . Griefs vary in effect, each introducing a unique survival challenge. These can include: Weapon Nerf, Ammo Drain, Zombie Ambush, Weapon Carousel, or Frozen. Learn how each one works below.

All Black Ops 6 Zombies Grief Types, Explained

Check out how each Black Ops 6 Zombies Grief works below:

  • Weapon Nerf: Affected players deal significantly reduced damage to zombies while this Grief is active.
  • Ammo Drain: Ammo is gradually depleted from affected players’ weapons, even if the weapon is stowed.
  • Zombie Ambush: An Elite zombie spawns and fights for the team that captured the zone. It ignores them and targets only the opposing team for one minute or until killed.
  • Weapon Carousel: Affected players’ weapons are randomly swapped every few seconds. At the end, they’re left with a random weapon, but its Pack-a-Punch status, rarity, and ammo mod are preserved.
  • Frozen: Affected players’ movement speed is reduced to half.

item.title: Lies of P Overture – How to Start the DLC
item.description:
Upon release, Lies of P checked many boxes for fans of the soulslike genre who had long awaited a spiritual successor to FromSoftware's Bloodborne. Neowiz, the developer behind Lies of P, happily took on that challenge. With the release of the Overture DLC, fans get to dive deeper into the incredible lore, and learn more about what happened before the events of the base game. It is important to note, however, that starting the new Lies of P DLC has some important requirements, which may not be readily apparent to some players. In this guide, we'll walk you through the steps, and show you how to begin the new Overture DLC in Lies of P .

How to Start the Overture Expansion in Lies of P

Story Progression Required:

While many players will be eager to jump into the new content that comes with the Overture DLC, there are certain steps you'll need to take before getting started. Unfortunately for new players, Overture has considerable progression requirements that you'll need to meet before jumping in. This means that you will not be able to simply start a new game and access the new content.

In order to begin the Overture expansion, you'll need to reach the end of Chapter 9 . This is the point in the game when the Krat Hotel is attacked, and many of the items inside the building are completely destroyed. As soon as you repair the Stargazer in the center of the main chamber, you'll receive a notice that you can now begin the DLC.

If you've already completed the game, and have not started New Game Plus, you should receive the item that allows you to begin Overture – called the Star's Chrysalis – as soon as you log into the game.

How to Use the Star's Chrysalis in Lies of P

Once you've obtained the Star's Chrysalis, you'll simply need to visit any Stargazer. You should see a new quest notification by the "Teleport to Another Stargazer" option . Look under the Chapter 5 Stargazer list, and you'll see the quest notification under the Path of the Pilgrim location. Travel to this location with the Star's Chrysalis in your inventory.

Once you arrive at the Path of the Pilgrim Stargazer, a cutscene will automatically begin. P will take out the Star's Chrysalis, which will lead to a trail of butterflies forming. Follow the trail to the old Stargazer that was covered in ivy. An Overture DLC popup will show up on screen. Check the prompt, and give confirmation that you want to start the DLC.

Another cutscene will begin, and you will be sent to the snowy first region in the Forgotten Time. This marks the official start of Lies of P 's new Overture DLC.

item.title: New Plague Tale Game Leaked Ahead of Reveal
item.description:
A new leak might have just revealed the existence and title of a new A Plague Tale game, just ahead of a potential showcase reveal. The most recent game in the series, A Plague Tale: Requiem , launched in 2022 on PC, PS5, Xbox Series X/S, and Nintendo Switch.

The Plague Tale series has been a particularly bright spot in the catalog of its developer, Asobo Studio. Once known for licensed titles and relatively low-profile releases, the studio's release of A Plague Tale: Innocence wowed players and critics alike with its high-quality visuals and evocative setting, as well as its narrative that depicted one of the best sibling relationships in gaming. Innocence starred a pair of siblings living in France during the time of the infamous Black Death, a continent-spanning plague spread by hordes of rats. The sequel, A Plague Tale: Requiem , expanded more on the supernatural aspects of Innocence , focusing on Amicia, the elder sister, and her struggle to protect her little brother from his condition as well as the sinister forces that would exploit it.

Thanks to an accidental leak from publisher Focus Entertainment on June 5, it seems that a third Plague Tale game is primed to be revealed. In a pair of now-deleted posts on its official Threads account, Focus Entertainment promoted the unveiling of a game called Resonance: A Plague Tale Legacy . The posts, which were archived by Twitter users like Wario64, included a brief teaser video showing glimpses of the game and revealing its target platforms and release window. Though Focus Entertainment has yet to officially confirm the leak, it's likely that Resonance: A Plague Tale Legacy will launch sometime in 2026 for Xbox Series X/S, PC, and PS5, and given the timing, it's possible that a proper reveal will take place at the Xbox Games Showcase on June 8. The leaked trailer did not mention the newly released Switch 2 as a target platform, though considering that both existing A Plague Tale games eventually saw release on the Switch 1, a future release on the Switch 2 doesn't seem out of the question.

Resonance: A Plague Tale Legacy Unveiling Accidentally Leaked Ahead of Showcase

The leaked Resonance: A Plague Tale Legacy announcement didn't reveal much about the game's premise, though a fair amount can be inferred from what was shown in the trailer, as well as from the title. The titling suggests that this story isn't necessarily a direct continuation of the events from previous games. The ending of A Plague Tale: Requiem was fairly definitive, so the use of " A Plague Tale Legacy " in the title of Resonance suggests that its story acknowledges Requiem 's events but isn't directly connected to them.

The second major clue is the game's featured character. The trailer and key art promoted in the leaked posts featured a character who looks to be Sophia, a seafarer introduced in Requiem . Considering Sophia's character arc and earlier comments from Asobo Studio that Requiem was the end of A Plague Tale , the use of "Legacy" in the title implies the beginning of a new series or subseries rather than a true sequel.

item.title: Simple But Fun Open-World Games
item.description:
Summary

  • Open-world games vary in complexity, but some, like Westerado, Dredge, or Terraria, excel in simplicity and immersive experiences.
  • Despite simple designs, these titles offer unique ideas, immersive worlds, easy controls, and engaging action for players.
  • From revenge quests to fishing trawlers and underground exploration, these games provide fun through accessibility and captivating atmospheres.

Open-world games can offer players expansive and dense experiences packed with gameplay systems and mechanics. Others are more straightforward, instead focusing on exploration. In any case, simplicity isn't always exercised, and sometimes complex gameplay loops or systems can get in the way.

There are a variety of open-world experiences, however, that excel in their simplicity. Despite having a simple core design, however, these titles remain fun via unique ideas, immersive worlds, and/or engaging action that makes use of their inherent accessibility.

8 Westerado: Double Barreled

Exploring A Pixel-Art Wild West

Westerado: Double Barreled
Indie Games
Action-Adventure
Systems
Released
April 16, 2015

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
t
Platform(s)
Microsoft Windows, macOS, Xbox One
Powered by

Westerado: Double Barreled wears its heart on its sleeve, offering a charming and nostalgic pixel-art aesthetic that matches its simple gameplay. In the game, players explore the Wild West, taking part in arcade shootouts as they search for the outlaw that murdered their family.

The game's simple set-up and controls ensure it is an intuitive and easy-to-grasp experience. But Westerado remains engaging thanks to its fast-paced action and unique gameplay loop, which itself provides surprising replay value.

7 Flotsam

Surviving In An Open Water World

  • Platform(s): PC
  • Released: 2019
  • Developer(s): Pajama Llama Games
  • Genre: Colony-Sim

Flotsam is a colony-sim that stands out with its unique setting, taking place in a watery post-apocalypse with a decidedly relaxed ambiance. As a colony-sim with an emphasis on management mechanics, Flotsam is remarkably simple, offering a more accessible experience that's still fun thanks to added exploration and its relaxed atmosphere.

In Flotsam , players build and manage a colony of drifters, attempting to survive on floating debris fixed together from odds and ends. It can get repetitive, but players that enjoy its simple gameplay and unique world will find a tranquil experience that's worth playing.

6 For The King

A Free-Form Strategy RPG

For The King
RPG
Systems
Released
April 19, 2018

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL

ESRB
T For Teen Due To Blood, Fantasy Violence
Developer(s)
Ironoak Games
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One
Powered by

For The King is a unique combination of strategy RPGs, roguelikes, and tabletop game mechanics. What results is a surprisingly elegant design that allows for immediate fun, offering accessibility with its simple combat and engagement via its RPG systems.

For The King's combat boils down to the use of abilities and items, but RNG plays a heavy role. This keeps combat from being too predictable and also makes for simpler decision-making. However, the ability to control this RNG with a unique resource does allow for added strategic thinking.

5 Dredge

Minimalist Fishing In An Open World

4 Images
4 Images
Dredge
10
8.2 /10
Released
March 31, 2023

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ Due To Animated Blood, Fantasy Violence, Mild Language, Use of Tobacco
Developer(s)
Black Salt Games
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox One, Xbox Series X
Powered by

Dredge wastes no time getting players into the meat of the experience, and this is possible thanks to its intuitive controls and simple design. In the game, players sail a small fishing boat around an archipelago haunted by eldritch horrors. It can get repetitive, but Dredge is elevated by its immersive atmosphere and addictive loop.

Dredge tasks players with gathering fish via a variety of intuitive mini-games, and although there's no real difficulty present, the simplicity of these activities allows players to better enjoy the ambiance. The day/night cycle also helps to direct players, with the day offering a relaxed environment and the night providing frequent spooks.

4 LEGO The Lord Of The Rings

A Simple & Intuitive Adventure

LEGO The Lord of the Rings: The Video Game
8.0 /10
Released
October 30, 2012

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ // Cartoon Violence, Comic Mischief
Developer(s)
Traveller's Tales, TT Fusion
Platform(s)
Android, iOS, Nintendo 3DS, Nintendo DS, PC, PS3, PlayStation Vita, Wii, Xbox 360
Powered by

As with many if not all LEGO games, LEGO The Lord Of The Rings maintains a simple blend of collecting, puzzle-solving, and low-stakes combat. This allows for instant accessibility that's still fun thanks to the variety of collectibles and simple but intuitive puzzles.

Perhaps the greatest strength of this simplicity is the accessibility it brings, making LEGO The Lord Of The Rings perfect for cooperative play. Furthermore, the open-world environments of LEGO The Lord Of The Rings are relatively optional, but for those that enjoy searching for collectibles, it offers a veritable treasure trove of content.

3 Outer Wilds

Minimalist But Awe-Inspiring Exploration

Outer Wilds
9.2 /10
Released
May 28, 2019

WHERE TO PLAY

DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
E10+ For Everyone 10+ due to Fantasy Violence, Alcohol Reference
Developer(s)
Mobius Digital
Platform(s)
PS4, Xbox One, PC
Powered by

Although Outer Wilds features little in the way of gameplay systems, its focus on exploration serves it well. This is thanks to a well-crafted world that's steeped in atmosphere, offering a memorable spacefaring adventure that certain players are sure to treasure.

Taking place across multiple planets, Outer Wilds tasks players with venturing across a minimalist solar system in search of answers. The unique nature of each planet's environments and the game's immersive spaceflight controls are clear strengths. However, it's the aforementioned atmosphere and excellent soundtrack that elevate Outer Wilds above and beyond its simple design.

2 The Long Dark

Simple But Hardcore Survival

The Long Dark
7.8 /10
Released
August 1, 2017

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T For Teen due to Blood, Language, Violence
Developer(s)
Hinterland Studio
Platform(s)
Nintendo Switch, PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One
Powered by

While it does feature a complex set of survival mechanics that are relatively hardcore, the actual gameplay loop of The Long Dark is rather simple. Players will spend most of their time walking across isolated environments and scavenging what they can from a variety of abandoned interiors, trying not to die somewhere along the way.

Managing to survive is where things get more complicated, as there are myriad threats - both alive and not - that can bring a run of The Long Dark to a swift and brutal end. However, it doesn't take long to get to grips with the basics, and players will quickly improve with simple trial and error.

1 Terraria

An Intuitive Survival-Craft Experience

Terraria
7 /10
17
9.4 /10
Released
May 16, 2011

WHERE TO PLAY

SUBSCRIPTION
DIGITAL
PHYSICAL

ESRB
T for Teen: Blood and Gore, Cartoon Violence, Mild Suggestive Themes, Use of Alcohol
Developer(s)
Re-Logic
Platform(s)
PC, Xbox 360, Xbox One, Xbox Series S, Xbox Series X, Vita, iOS, Android, macOS, Linux, 3DS, Stadia, PlayStation 3, PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Nintendo Switch
Powered by

Terraria is an intuitive survival-craft experience that excels with its procedural open-world environments, particularly in its variety of underground areas. Supporting the exploration aspects of the game is a diverse set of systems and mechanics. These cover everything from crafting and base-building to town management and tense combat, offering a truly dynamic experience.

Despite the sheer variety of Terraria's content, however, it is a relatively straightforward experience. This is thanks primarily to its intuitive user-interface and simple controls that allow the base-building and combat to be a frustration-free experience.

item.title: Mario Kart World Review
item.description:
Mario Kart 8 Deluxe is one of the best-selling games of all time with over 68 million units sold and counting, so it's really no surprise that Nintendo decided to launch the Switch 2 with its followup, Mario Kart World . The Switch 2's flagship launch title, Mario Kart World expands the established Mario Kart formula with some wild new features while still staying true to what fans love about the series in the first place.

Mario Kart World delivers more of the same chaotic racing action as its predecessors, but bigger and better. Playing Mario Kart World on a docked Switch 2 in 4K is a visual treat, with vibrant colors, impressive animations, and a large open world that is rendered with zero performance issues of any kind. From a technical and graphical standpoint, Mario Kart World is incredibly impressive and a showcase of what the Switch 2 is capable of. What stuck out to me the most was the shifting weather as I sped across the game world, with dark thunderstorms giving way to gorgeous sunsets that had me stop and take in the sights. Mario Kart has always looked great, but Mario Kart World takes things to the next level.

Mario Kart World 's stunning visuals pair well with its fantastic soundtrack, typical of Nintendo. Different areas and tracks have their associated tunes, with new music mixed in with nostalgic throwbacks. The game is full of iconic sound effects and little audio touches that go a long way in giving Mario Kart World endless personality. From the frantic slot machine sound when players pick up an item to Pauline singing whenever players perform tricks with her off a jump, Mario Kart World 's brilliant sound design stands tall alongside its eye-popping graphics to deliver an often jaw-dropping presentation.

Presentation-wise, Mario Kart World is practically perfect, and while one would normally expect some of its visual splendor or performance to be compromised when playing in split-screen, that is absolutely not the case in my testing. Mario Kart World runs beautifully in single-player and in split-screen multiplayer, with players once again able to enjoy up to 4-player split-screen with friends. Two players can even play in split-screen against others online, which is much appreciated.

Mario Kart World is Full of Fun Game Modes

Mario Kart World features the standard game modes that one has come to expect from the franchise over the years. Of course, the flagship Grand Prix mode is back in Mario Kart World , with each cup a joy to race through. Mario Kart World tweaks the typical Grand Prix set-up by having players race on each track for a single lap, and then literally drive to the next track as part of the same, ongoing race. All of Mario Kart World 's tracks are stunning and fun to race on. There truly isn't a bad track in the bunch, and players will have a ton of fun seeing what each one has to offer.

Battle Mode is also back, slicing sections of Mario Kart World 's map into arenas for players to duke it out match types like the classic Balloon Battle and Coin Runners. Battle Mode is always good for some laughs, and that's no different in Mario Kart World , with players able to enjoy it locally or online.

The standout new game mode in Mario Kart World is Knockout Tour, where players have to finish each race in a certain position or avoid being eliminated. Knockout Tour is challenging and hard to put down. I found myself playing it for hours, chasing after the elusive goal of finally winning one of Knockout Tour's high-stakes 24-player races.

Mario Kart World expands races to include 24 players, and while that may sounds daunting on paper, it works well. Thanks to the added horsepower of the Switch, Mario Kart World achieves 24-player races without compromising performance at all. Bumping up the racer count also gave Nintendo an excuse to give Mario Kart World the franchise's most-varied roster of characters to date, with the usual mainstays joined by surprise characters like a literal cow and penguin. Many of the returning Mario Kart racers have unlockable outfits that count as individual racers, plus there are plenty of different vehicles to earn as well, ensuring near-endless variety even without MK8 Deluxe 's kart customization.

Mario Kart World's Free Roam Leaves A Lot to Be Desired

When it comes to the returning Mario Kart game modes and Knockout Tour, Mario Kart World defies expectations. Unfortunately, the game's defining new mode, Free Roam, is a massive disappointment. One of the most-hyped modes leading up to release, Mario Kart World 's Free Roam gives players the chance to freely explore a huge map that connects all the game's tracks. The open world is filled with P-Switches that unlock challenging missions for players to complete in exchange for rewards, along with collectible coins and other secrets to discover.

Mario Kart World 's open world is visually-impressive, and there is some fun to be had exploring and trying to complete all the missions. The problem is that Free Roam lacks direction. It plops players into the middle of it and lets them fast-travel anywhere right off the bat, doing anything they want with no sense of progression. What makes matters worse is that the game does not keep track of completed missions on the map, which makes trying to do everything a needlessly overwhelming task. This is a big oversight, and hopefully Nintendo patches in a way for players to have a better understanding of what they've already done and where they still have missions to complete.

Exploring Mario Kart World 's Free Roam map in multiplayer is also disappointing. P-Switches disappear when playing in co-op, and there really isn't anything to do with friends in the open world. It's a glorified lobby for the races, and that's a real shame. But while Mario Kart World 's take on the open world concept doesn't quite hit the mark, there is obvious potential there, and I hope future installments do the idea justice.

I am disappointed with Mario Kart World 's Free Roam, but the game nails everything else. It's good for near-endless hours of entertainment, and it will definitely stay in my Switch 2 rotation for years to come. Mario Kart World is the best the series has ever looked or played and a definite must-have for Switch 2 early adopters.

7 Images
7 Images

Pros & Cons
  • The best Mario Kart has ever looked
  • Exciting, chaotic 24-player races on some series-best tracks
  • Huge roster of playable characters that all have a ton of personality
  • Knockout Tour's challenge makes it impossible to put down
  • Free Roam and the open world are lackluster
